title: Performance difference between Vector and Array

labels.name: I-slow
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to performance of generated code.

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
On most platforms, the same Audio DSP algorithm runs slower when its buffer is backed by a `Vector` compared an `Array`.
The difference in speed measured in favor of `Array` vs `Vector` is typically -10% to +60%

Due to the large performance gains observed especially on simpler and slower CPUs, it is tempting to replace idiomatic code by macros generating multiple functions which accept only fixed-size `Array` input.
Otherwise, when performance matters it appears preferable to always work with slices of `Array` buffers of the maximum size needed instead of `Vector` unless they have to be dynamically resized.

Note however that in this test, while the Rust implementation is often slower than GCC C++ with vector-backed buffers, it is usually close to the speed of when compiled by Clang C++ which is already good.

This [repository](https://github.com/supercurio/rust-vec-array-perf) contains Rust and C++ benchmarks for comparison.
I collected [results on desktop, laptop, smartphone and tablets CPUs](https://github.com/supercurio/rust-vec-array-perf/tree/master/results), so you can see how much variation can be observed.

Rust versions: 1.14, 1.15.1, 1.16
